Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2011, Intersections of Biology and Mathematical and Physical Sciences. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow at the intersection of biology and engineering. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Jonathan Dyhr is "Multisensory control of insect flight." The host institution for this research is the University of Washington, Seattle with sponsoring scientists Drs. Thomas Daniel and Kristi Morgansen.

Coordinated animal movement requires combining multiple and different types of sensory information whether the movement is on land, in water, or in air through flight. Moving organisms must parallel process many changing and complex sensory signals. Individually, these signals carry limited information about the world and are transmitted with varying latencies and levels of precision. This research applies quantitative techniques and tools from control theory to better understand how the hawkmoth, Manduca sexta, integrates sensory information to orchestrate appropriate behavioral responses during flight. First, the roles of different sensory systems for maintaining flight stability are measured in freely flying moths as they recover from external visual and mechanical perturbations. Second, a control theoretic model of the moth flight control system is used to characterize the sensitivity of the system to different parameters, such as the transmission delay of sensory signals. This research establishes a control theoretic toolbox for studying biological systems.

Experimentally advantageous invertebrate model systems, such as M. sexta, provide key insights into the basic neural processes that underlie motor control and new experimental techniques that are economical. Furthermore, broader impacts include potential applications for treating motor deficits, developing better prosthetic strategies, and designing biologically inspired robots. Specific training objectives for the Fellow include expanding expertise in control theory and biomechanics, gaining teaching experience by designing an undergraduate short course on control systems in biology, gaining experience mentoring high school and undergraduate students, and assisting the Pacific Science Center with new exhibits for communicating science to public audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When animals move through the environment they perform many complex tasks, including avoiding obstacles, searching for food, predicting the movements of other animals, sensing danger and responding to environmental obstacles. The apparent ease of their movement disguises the difficult of overcoming these challenges. Even our most advanced robotic systems can only accomplish a fraction of these tasks, much less do them without human input.

Understanding how animals perform these tasks requires tools to determine how animals sense their environment, how their brain work to process sensory information and how that information is used to coordinate movement. This research project addressed these challenges by developing a mathematical toolbox for identifying how animals transform sensory inputs (e.g. vision) into movement. These tools were tested using an experimentally advantageous insect model systems, the hawkmoth Manduca sexta. Using an insect model system allowed us to test a particular difficult and unstable method of locomotion, flight, which is primarily controlled using vision. This allowed for a direct link between sensory processing and motor movements.

Our results suggest that animals use strategies that are different from human engineered systems. Animals do not carefully control a few motors using very accurate sensors. Instead, they use many individual, relatively unreliable sensors to coordinate a large number of motors (muscles). Furthermore, these motors perform partially overlapping tasks. The large numbers of sensors and motors makes the system more complicated, in that there are more individual parts that need to work together. However, when we look at the behavior of the system as a whole where the actions of these many sensors and motors are combined, the actual movement strategies appear to be mathematically simple.

Furthermore, our results suggest that there are advantage to using many different sensors and motors for movement. First, these many systems provide a fail-safe mechanism should any individual component stop working. Second, by using many different sensors and motors, animals appear to overcome traditional engineering trade-offs, such as being agile (able to move quickly in response to stimuli) while remaining stable (able to maintain control despite external disturbances).

While this project used an insect model system, the techniques and mathematical toolbox developed for the project can be applied to any system, including improving our understanding of how the human body and brain work. The work also has the potential to transform the way we design robotic systems through the application of these movement strategies to human designed systems.

While our results strongly suggest that there are striking advantages to the ways in which animals move, we still do not know why this might be true. Future work will seek to confirm these findings and uncover exactly how animals are able to perform incredibly acrobatic maneuvers with deceptive ease.
